posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
We’ve had great success using the Arm example of the MotionMagic Position Control. It works great! Completely vertical is 90, completely horizontal on either side is 180 and 0.

It has left me wondering however, how does the motor controller know not to rotate through the base of the robot?

My guess is it has an understanding of the direction you want to go based on the KF value. But if I start at say 210 degress (which would be really low), and tell it I want to go to -10 which would be low on the other side… what stops it from determining its quickest path is through the Robot?

My other guess is because I’m commanding -10 (go a little below fully horizontal) and not a value like 350? But I want to learn for sure! We do have limit switches on each end (to avoid being able to rotate through the robot!) but that does not have anything to do with a position calculation.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
is there any spot I should reach out to CTRE on this?

I’m really currious how this works and how the controller seems to know to not try to go throught he bottom of the robot!

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked: Thought about it. Must be correlated wjth a negative KF to tell it what direction to travel!

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Can you share the example you’re looking at? I’m not finding one that matches your description.

If i’m understanding your question correctly, this would be the case if your PID controller is wrapping from 0-360. In this case, then it would indeed move through your robot base to go along the shortest path to your setpoint. However, if your controller isn’t wrapping around, then it will go the “farther route” from 210 to -10  (210 → 0 → -10)

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
It’s as simple as applying the PID calculation to the error. If you are at 210 and make the setpoint -10, the error is 220. To correct the error, negative output must be applied.

As @Sumifairy noted, the sensor value doesn’t wrap around at 360-degrees. It doesn’t even know it’s attached to an arm that rotates.

In fact, on mechanics that do spin infinitely, like the steering on a swerve drive module, your code would have to calculate the shortest path. The controller doesn’t know that 10 and 370 are the same position of the mechanic.

Final note, CTRE recently added continuous PID, but you have to buy Phoenix Pro to use it, and Phoenix Pro doesn’t support Motion Magic (yet.)

posts.name: Rick Lance
posts.cooked: If I’m reading this correctly you have to constantly call the set operation and send it a new FeedForward since the angle of the arm is constantly changing during its motion.   That angle calculation for the 2nd and 3rd joints in the arm will be a good exercise for the students to figure out.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: That’s right. You have to constantly recalculate the feedforward, based on gravity.

posts.name: Omar Zrien CTR-Electronics Co-owner
posts.cooked:
Motion Magic was added in the kickoff release - it is also enhanced a bit.

Motion Magic now has a new Jerk config in rot/s^3, (which replaces the coarse S-Curve strength config from Phoenix 5).  So now you have better control of how much S-Curving you want (in canonical units).

It also syncs to the mechanism if it enters MM with non-zero initial velocity - which Phoenix v5 firmware didn’t support (just starts with target velocity of zero when you start it).

And the way the new firmware and API works, your output units can be duty-cycle or voltage or torque-current.  Which means that the numerator for your gains are in the same units based on whatever you want.  So for example, if you like to specify things in volts, its volts all the way down (feedforward, gains, etc.).  If you prefer duty-cycle or torque-current, then its duty-cycle all the way down. This is actually true for all the modes, including MM.

The TalonFX has a variety of open-loop and closed-loop control requests and supports Field Oriented Control. Control Output Types: The TalonFX supports three base control types: DutyCycle, Voltage,...

And you can use MM with FOC (selectable-FOC if its voltage or duty-cycle based, always FOC for torque-current)

The TalonFX has a variety of open-loop and closed-loop control requests and supports Field Oriented Control. Control Output Types: The TalonFX supports three base control types: DutyCycle, Voltage,...
